I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, (ii) a proposed grant to the Kingdom of Cambodia, 
and  (iii)  a  proposed  grant  to  the  Lao  People's  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR),  all  for  the 
Second Greater Mekong Subregion Regional Communicable Diseases Control Project. 
 
2. 
The 5-year project builds on the achievements and lessons learned from the first Greater 
Mekong Subregion Regional Communicable Diseases Control Project (RCDCP),1 which played 
a  major  role  in  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  in  containing  the  spread  of  emerging 
diseases,  improving  provincial  health  systems  and  communicable  disease  control  (CDC)  in 
vulnerable  groups,  and  strengthening  regional  cooperation.  The  project  will  further  enhance 
regional  cooperation  capacity,  expanded 
regional  CDC  systems, 
surveillance  and  response  systems,  and  targeted  support  for  the  control  of  dengue  and 
neglected tropical diseases (NTDs).2 It will also improve provincial capacity for CDC, including 
staff training and community-based CDC in border districts. The project will particularly benefit 
the poor and ethnic groups in border districts, especially women and children.3

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Emerging infectious diseases such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), avian 
influenza, and swine flu have had major economic impacts on productivity, trade, and tourism in 
the GMS, and continue to pose a major public health concern. New diseases, mostly of animal 
origin,  also  pose  a  constant  threat.  Dengue,  chikungunya,  cholera,  typhoid,  and  HIV/AIDS—
fueled  by  better  connectivity,  urban  development,  and  social  and  environment  changes—
continue to spread in the GMS. Controlling these diseases requires strong surveillance systems, 
community prevention and preparedness, and quick system response capacities. 
 
4. 
Leaders  of  the  GMS  have  given  high  priority  to  the  control  of  emerging  diseases,  and 
more  recently  also  dengue  and  NTDs.  All  GMS  countries  endorse  and  seek  to  implement  the 
new International Health Regulations (World Health Organization [WHO], 2005) for the reporting 
and containment of outbreaks and disasters of international concern. Several regional strategies 
are  being  rolled  out,  including  the  Asia  Pacific  Strategy  for  Emerging  Diseases  (APSED),  and 
strategies  for  the  control  of  dengue  and  NTDs.  GMS  governments  are  fully  committed  to 
implementing these strategies, and to strengthening provincial health systems to support CDC. 
With  increased  connectivity,  CDC  needs  closer  attention—forecasting,  risk  mitigation,  and 
reinforcing  public  health  fundamentals—so  as  to  contain  transmission  of  and  exposure  to 
pathogens, and this requires a multisector approach. However, the immediate need is to contain 
any  new  outbreak.  While  Southeast  Asia  has  been  the  center  of  emerging  diseases, 
surveillance  and  response  systems,  community  preparedness,  and  health  system  support  in 
Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam are still not up to the standards of neighboring countries.

 2 

 

 

Under the GMS program, the RCDCP was initiated in 2005 in partnership with the WHO, 
5. 
and  closed  in  2010.  The  ministries  of  health  (MOHs)  are  highly  appreciative  of  the  RCDCP, 
which  was  very  timely  with  the  outbreak  of  avian  influenza,  escalation  of  dengue,  and  an 
emerging HIV/AIDS epidemic in the Lao PDR. The RCDCP strengthened provincial surveillance 
and  outbreak  response  capacity  and  provided  provinces  with  a  flexible  response  capacity  to 
deal with disease outbreaks. Within 36 targeted provinces, the RCDCP also built up provincial 
health  systems  capacity  for  CDC.  The  third  output  (regional  capacity  building  for  CDC) 
supported  regional  cooperation  capacity  and  knowledge  management,  and  harmonizing 
regional  strategies  for  disease  control  and  cross-border  cooperation.  A  regional  coordination 
unit  (RCU)  for  building  regional  coordination  and  knowledge  management,  and  international 
consultants, were financed through a regional pooled fund managed by the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB).  Benefits  of  regional  approaches  are  emerging  in  terms  of  information  exchange, 
joint strategic planning, and cross-border disease control efforts.  
 
6. 
Important  lessons  have  been  learned  in  the  RCDCP.  First,  the  RCDCP  experienced 
some initial delay in Cambodia as it became effective just after the annual budget cycle, and in 
Viet  Nam  due  to  staff  constraints  and  lengthy  procurement  procedures.  The  project  will  use 
current  RCDCP  project  management  units  (PMUs)  and  advance  action  to  reduce  start-up 
delays.  Second,  the  geographic  targeting  of  the  RCDCP  was  not  optimal;  the  project  will 
therefore  focus  on  border  districts  and  remote  communities.  A  better  prepared  and  resourced 
gender action plan (GAP) and ethnic group plan and better monitoring and evaluation will also 
help improve targeting. Third, training activities remained highly centralized; the project will help 
establish provincial training systems to improve provincial training capacity. Fourth, community-
based dengue control was less sustainable, and needs to be improved further with support of 
experts.  Fifth,  regional  cooperation  and  knowledge  management  were  slow  to  emerge;  the 
project will help strengthen the institutional capacity of each MOH in these areas.    
 
The  project  follows  Strategy  2020,4 which  realigns  ADB's  role  in  the  health  sector  with 
7. 
emphasis  on  regional,  intersector,  and  interagency  cooperation,  as  also  detailed  in  the 
operational  plan  for  health. 5  It  is  in  line  with  ADB’s  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration 
Strategy,6 the  GMS  regional  cooperation  strategy7 and  the  country  partnership  strategies  and 
country operations business plans of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam.8 The project supports 
regional  public  goods  and  capacity  towards  regional  health  and  economic  security  and  the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for reducing child mortality and malnutrition, halting the 
spread  of  communicable  diseases,  and  others.  In  partnership  with  WHO,  the  Mekong  Basin 
Disease  Surveillance  Cooperation,  the  Kenan  Institute  Asia  and  other  partners,  it  addresses 
critical funding gaps for the roll-out of the International Health Regulations (2005) and APSED, 
as well as regional strategies for the control of dengue and NTDs. Under the leadership of WHO, 
regional  and  national  aid  coordination  mechanisms  are  in  place  including  regular  meetings, 
surveys and publications for aid coordination, technical forums, community of practice groups, 
and websites.9

3

Impact and Outcome 

B. 
 
8. 
The  project  impact  is  improved  health  of  the  population  in  the  GMS.  The  expected 
project  outcome  will  be  timely  and  adequate  control  of  communicable  diseases  of  regional 
relevance (see Appendix 1 for indicators).   
 
C. 

Outputs 

Based  on  achievements  and  lessons  learned  in  the  RCDCP,  three  outputs  have  been 
9. 
formulated: (i) enhanced regional CDC systems, (ii) improved CDC along borders and economic 
corridors, and (iii) integrated project management.  
 
The  first  output  supports  regional  and  national  disease  surveillance  and  control.  The 
10. 
second output will focus on 38 provinces10 for capacity building; and 1,160 lagging villages with 
a total population of about 1.7 million in 116 border districts for community-based CDC. For the 
second output, efforts have been made to make the clusters of targeted provinces contiguous. 
Three  clusters  have  been  identified:  (i)  the  northern  corridor  in  Viet  Nam  and  the  Lao  PDR 
bordering the People’s Republic of China; (ii) the central corridor in central Viet Nam, southern 
Lao  PDR,  and  northeast  Cambodia;  and  (iii)  the  southern  corridor  between  Viet  Nam  and 
Cambodia, connecting to Thailand.  
 
11. 
The  selection  of  provinces  was  based  on  these  having  major  links  with  neighboring 
countries,  and  being  considered  major  corridors  for  the  spread  of  communicable  diseases. 
Prioritization  of  villages  in  targeted  districts  will  be  based  on  needs,  vulnerability,  connectivity, 
and  feasibility.  At  least  half  of  the  targeted  population  in  the  villages  will  belong  to  ethnic 
minority groups. The third output will support PMUs and project implementation units under the 
administrative umbrella of the assigned department in each MOH.    
 

1. 

Output 1: Enhanced Regional Communicable Disease Control Systems 

12. 
Improved  capacity  for  regional  cooperation  in  communicable  disease  control. 
Building on the RCDCP, the project will further enhance regional cooperation in CDC to achieve 
(i) improved MOH capacity for regional cooperation in CDC, (ii) coordinated implementation of 
regional strategies, and (iii) sustained knowledge management. The project will strengthen focal 
points in each MOH for regional CDC coordination and knowledge management; and assist the 
WHO and the ministries to roll out and strengthen regional CDC strategies, including APSED. 
The project will also support each MOH to participate in regional activities, including the regional 
steering  committee  and  project  workshops;  and  continue  knowledge  management  activities 
initiated  under  the  RCDCP,  including  technical  forums  and  community  of  practice  for  dengue, 
Japanese encephalitis, laboratory services, cross-border activities, NTDs, and human resource 
development. The project will seek regional partnerships for the CDC clearing house and other 
CDC activities such as standard setting and policy-related studies. An RCU based in MOH, the 
Lao PDR, will continue to coordinate regional activities and support the knowledge management 
program. ADB will manage a small part of the grants for the financing of joint activities.   
 
13. 
Expanded  surveillance  and  response  systems.  ADB  will  continue  to  support 
provincial  capacity  for  outbreak  investigation  and  response.  Output  1  will  support  (i)  regional 
coordination  of  surveillance  and  response  systems,  (ii)  provincial  surveillance  and  response

capacity and financing outbreak control, (iii) improving quality of laboratory services, (iv) scaling 
up cross-border cooperation, and (v) improving outbreak reporting systems for major hospitals. 
The  project  will  seek  partnership  with,  and  if  possible  support,  the  Mekong  Basin  Disease 
Surveillance Cooperation and other partners for cross-border activities.  
  
14. 
Targeted  support  for  emerging  and  neglected  diseases.  The  project  will  also 
continue  to  provide  targeted  support  for  dengue  and  NTDs,  including  Japanese  encephalitis, 
soil-transmitted  helminthiasis,  opisthorchiasis,  schistosomiasis,  and  filariasis.  This  will  include   
(i)  joint  assessments  of  the  spread  and  determinants  of  dengue  and  NTDs  along  economic 
corridors;  and  (ii)  effective  control  measures  including  behavioral  change  communication, 
equipment, vaccines, and medical supplies.   
 

2. 

Output  2:  Improved  Communicable  Disease  Control  along  Borders  and 
Economic Corridors 
 

15. 
Improved  community-based  communicable  disease  control.  Border  areas  are  at 
higher risk of disease outbreaks due to their proximity to borders and economic corridors, while 
at  the  same  time  having  access  problems  combined  with  weak  health  systems  and  less-
informed  and  endowed  communities.  Many  of  these  communities  are  ethnic  groups,  new 
settlements,  or  peri-urban  migrants.  Under  this  sub-output,  the  project  will  target  about  1,160 
poor,  remote  communities  (on  average  two  per  year  per  district)  with  a  total  estimated 
population  of  1.76  million  in  116  border  districts  in  38  provinces—16  in  Viet  Nam,  10  in 
Cambodia,  and  12  in  the  Lao  PDR.  This  will  include  (i)  training  of  village  health  workers,          
(ii) participatory assessment and planning, (iii) community  preparedness and school education 
campaigns, (iv) cross-border cooperation, and (v) accelerated healthy village development.    
  
16. 
Improved  staff  capacity  in  communicable  disease  control.  To  improve  provincial 
capacity on a more sustainable basis, the project will build a provincial training system in each 
of the 38 targeted provinces based on policies, standards, and local potential. This will include 
(i)  setting  up  a  provincial  training  group,  (ii)  improving  human  resources  management,             
(iii)  developing  a  provincial  in-service  training  system  for  the  sector,  (iv)  improving  staff 
performance,  and  (v)  reducing  staff  gaps  by  providing  scholarships  for  field  epidemiology  and 
ethnic  persons  for  training  as  health  staff.  This  will  require,  among  other  things,  training  of 
trainers and equipping provincial schools.    

 

3. 

Output 3: Integrated Project Management 

17. 
The  third  output  will  support  effective  and  sustainable  project  management  through 
PMUs, project implementation units, and national implementation units under the administrative 
umbrella of each MOH subsector program. This includes support for (i) provincial stewardship, 
management  capacity,  and  results-based  management;  (ii)  improving  procurement,  financial 
management, and technical support; and (iii) mainstreaming and sustaining project activities in 
provincial  annual  operational  plans  including  provincial  training  systems,  special  support  for 
isolated  communities,  compliance  with  social  safeguards,  adequate  recurrent  budget,  and 
monitoring and evaluation.

Investment and Financing Plans 

The project is estimated to cost $54.00 million including contingencies of $5.60 million. 

D.

19.

grants  from  its  Special  Funds  resources  (90.7%  of  the  project  amount)  to  help  finance  the 
project: the Government of Viet Nam has requested a loan of $27.0 million with a 32-year term, 
including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period

agreement.  The  Government  of  Cambodia  has  requested  a  grant  not  exceeding  $10.0  million

2). About 5% of the grants will be pooled as under the RCDCP, and managed by ADB based on

equivalent—Cambodia $1.00 million, the Lao PDR $1.00 million, and Viet Nam $3.00 million—in 
cash  (Viet  Nam  only),  taxes  and  duties,  government  contributions  in  kind  (staff  salaries, 
facilities, recurrent costs), and community contributions in kind.

Implementation Arrangements 

20. 
The  MOH  in  each  country  will  be  the  executing  agency.  Each  executing  agency  has 
overall  responsibility  for  in-country  project  implementation  and  coordination  among  countries. 
Each  executing  agency  has  a  project  director  from  among  its  senior  officials  for  project 
management  and  liaison  with  ADB.  National  departments,  institutions,  and  provincial  health 
departments are implementing agencies. The RCU will manage a small regional fund of about 
5% of total grant funds drawn from the Cambodia and Lao PDR grants for regional activities and 
some  international  consulting  services.  Viet  Nam  will  allocate  and  manage  a  similar  amount 
under  its  loan  for  in-country  regional  workshops  and  international  consulting  services.  The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the project 
administration manual (PAM).11

A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Emerging diseases have had a major economic impact in the GMS, and new diseases 
21. 
are expected at the rate of about one per year, posing a constant health hazard.12 The project, 
by  strengthening  the  regional  surveillance  and  response  capacity,  will  help  curb  epidemics 
resulting  in  reduced  economic  losses,  mortality,  morbidity,  and  medical  costs.  The  project  will 
also  target  about  1.7  million  people  in  1,160  villages  in  116  border  districts,  and  within  these 
districts target remote communities. While overall about 31% of the district population belongs 
to  various  ethnic  groups,  the  project  will  aim  for  half  of  the  targeted  population  being  ethnic 
minorities.  These  communities  lag  behind  in  health  indicators,  in  large  part  due  to  common 
infectious  diseases  including  NTDs.  For  most  NTDs,  highly  cost-effective  interventions  are 
available,  such  as  vaccines  or  low-cost  medicine.  Bringing  these  diseases  under  control  also 
requires  cross-border  cooperation.  Some  25%  of  the  people  in  border  districts  will  directly 
benefit from project investments that will help them progress toward health-related MDGs. The 
poor, women and children will be the major beneficiaries of these community-level interventions.  
 
22. 
Technical  challenges  include  (i)  strengthening  regional  cooperation  and  knowledge 
management  for  CDC  on  a  sustainable  basis;  (ii)  accessing  border  districts  and  communities; 
(iii)  community-based  dengue  control;  and  (iv)  integrating  cross-border  cooperation,  training, 
and  social  safeguards  in  provincial  planning  and  budgeting.  The  project  provides  for  capacity 
building and initial support in these areas, and also includes several assurances. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

23. 
The economic analysis provides the rationale for public sector involvement, a discussion 
on provider options, the possible financial effect of the project, expected public sector behavior, 
and an estimated economic internal rate of return of 28%. The benefits of the project will come 
from  (i)  helping  prevent  major  epidemics;  (ii) productivity  gains  from  a  reduced  burden  of 
diseases;  (iii) productivity  gains  from  improved  achievements  in  education,  especially  through 
less  absenteeism  and  reduced  drop  out  rates;  and  (iv)  public  and  private  savings  in  health 
expenditures, including indirect costs. However, some of these benefits are difficult to measure. 
Only items (i) and (ii) were considered in the economic internal rate of return.   
 
24. 
The  project’s  recurrent  costs  represent  only  a  minor  percentage  of  government  health 
expenditure  as  a  percentage  of  domestic  spending  on  health—0.1%  in  Viet  Nam,  0.3%  in 
Cambodia,  and  1.3%  in  the  Lao  PDR.  The  figure  for  the  Lao  PDR  is  quite  high  because 
domestic  spending  is  very  low  at  $1.5  per  person  per  year.  Government  expenditures  for 
recurrent costs are increasing, indicating future sustainability of the project.

C.

and has staff with skills and experience in ADB procedures. Arrangements have been made to 
further  improve  administrative  and  financial  management  practices.  The  governments  have 
given  assurances

26. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed

Poverty and Social 

D. 

27. 
The targeted border districts have a high proportion of families living below or near the 
poverty  line  who  depend  heavily  on  the  availability  of  a  healthy  labor  force  in  the  family.  Any 
serious  disease  or  death  in  the  family  may  throw  the  family  into  even  deeper  poverty, 
malnutrition,  and  ill  health.  Improved  connectivity  is  facilitating  the  spread  of  communicable 
diseases  such  as  HIV,  emerging  diseases,  dengue,  and  NTDs.  People  in  border  districts  are 
less informed about these hazards, including trafficking and migrant labor, and have less access 
to  services.  By  helping  improve  regional  health  and  economic  security,  the  project  will  protect 
the poor against catastrophic events, and improve their health, learning, and productivity. 
 
Gender is a significant variable for understanding the spread of communicable diseases, 
28. 
as well as designing and delivering appropriate communicable disease prevention and control. 
Women  and  girls  have  specific  health  needs  and  are  the  usual  custodians  for  the  prevention, 
detection,  and  care  of  infectious  diseases  amongst  family  members.  Although  the  majority  of 
health  staff  are  often  female,  women  are  more  often  in  lower-level  positions.  Only  Cambodia 
has a policy of having both female and male village health workers. Increasing gender equity in 
health staff will improve CDC outcomes. To ensure the effectiveness of gender mainstreaming 
and  gender-related  outcomes  in  the  project,  each  MOH  will  fully  implement  the  GAP,  key 
features of which are mirrored in the project design and monitoring framework, loan assurances, 
and PAM. The GAP is aligned with national and sector-specific gender equality commitments in 
Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam.13 

 
Safeguards 

E. 

29. 
Ethnic groups constitute 31% of the population in the targeted border districts, most of 
them  in  the  Lao  PDR.  They  suffer  disproportionately  from  common  communicable  diseases, 
and  have  less  access  to  health  care  because  of  physical,  financial,  language,  and  cultural 
barriers.  The  project  is  assessed  category  B  for  indigenous  people  and  is  expected  to  have 
positive impacts on ethnic groups. The accrual of benefits to ethnic groups is discussed in the 
ethnic  groups  plan,  and  included  in  the  project  design.  Under  the  sub-output  for  community-
based  CDC,  the  aim  is  that  50%  of  1,160  targeted  villages  belong  to  ethnic  groups.  This 
includes  training  of  village  health  workers  and  support  for  healthy  village  development.  The 
project will also provide scholarships for ethnic group members to become health workers. The 
project is assessed category C for both environment and involuntary resettlement.

F. 
 
30.

commitment  for  health  sector  development,  all  of  which  will  have  long-term  value  across  the
